job_title: Team Leader in Woodstock, IL
pros: Everything except the money you make.
cons: The pay is low considering my education.

review_title: Great place to work in the mental health field!
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: I had a great time working at Thresholds! Definitely my best experience working in the mental health field. Everyone is dedicated to the mission of helping the clients, this is big as I have worked at places where your coworkers are clearly just coming in for a paycheck. There is a big emphasis on making sure staff are doing okay and not feeling burnt out. My supervisors did a lot to help accommodate my needs. There is a lot of room for staff to move up, and they work with you if you want to pursue a masters while working. You get to make a lot of decisions for your schedule. I was able to go home early or finish my work from home most days.
cons: Bare in mind it is a big company so my experience is only relevant to the Bridge North program. - A lot of driving to clients - Medicaid productivity requirements - High potential for burnout - The pay isn't great but better than many other places in the field

job_title: Program Director in Chicago, IL
pros: Almost everything. Most staff are great. Mission is incredible. Members are a delight to work with. Mark Ishaug is a strong, visionary leader. Benefits and time off is excellent.
cons: The employee relations (ER) department is incompetent, inconsistent, frequently condescending and rude, and there is no system in place to hold them accountable. They consistently provide terrible advice that is negatively hurting staff throughout the agency. Multiple (nearly all) program directors have voiced concerns that they do not feel safe or protected by ER, but nothing is ever done. Pay- As a program director overseeing 40 staff, I make less than a team leader (two levels below me) with 2 staff, because there are no caps on pay ranges. New team leaders are coming in just 20k under me. I've watched front line staff get raise after raise and they just don't seem to care about leadership or the amount of work that is expected of me and the stress that I am put under daily.

job_title: Case Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: High value in pt care, working with interdisciplinary team
cons: Poor work life balance, poor pay, high turnover which means intense work for staff still present

job_title: Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Super interesting work, contribute to a good cause, great co-workers
cons: Not enough pay, stressful at times

review_title: I have never been so anxious and depressed.
job_title: Community Support in Chicago, IL
pros: flexibility when doing notes and pto. There are good moments with some members who put in the work to improve.
cons: you must love this work to be able to do this job, members are extremely difficult to work with at times, some have body odor. be prepared to be in some gnarly conditions, if you like driving in the city this job is for you. you will put a ton of mileage on your car, constantly working based on the member's time, and not your own, so there is no way to keep up with workload without going over time. overall worst job experience i have ever had

job_title: Outreach Worker in Chicago, IL

review_title: Great mission, great training, often under staffed
job_title: Community Support Worker in Chicago, IL

review_title: Okay beginner job for the Social Work Field
job_title: Community Support Worker in Chicago, IL
pros:
Get to work from home.
Create your own schedule (if you like that).
Are only required to go into the office for meetings and filing paperwork.
They reimburse your gas mileage and will pay for member meals.
No one babysits you to do your work, you're treated like an adult.
Friendly management.
cons:
Must be able to work independently.
You have to drive your car around to visit clients.
There is a "productivity requirement" that can seem anxiety inducing for people new to the field.
A focus on writing notes over quality of care. 
Your training is all up to the person you follow.
Takes a good 4-6 months to get used to the job, all the paperwork, resources and so forth.
Must be an organized and self-motivated person.
Most of the Supervisors seem to be overwhelmed with paperwork.
Due to having notes due at the end of the week if you take a long time to write or visit clients on the south side you might find yourself working past 5 PM writing notes.

job_title: Team Leader in Chicago, IL
pros: Fantastic mission and values. Does incredible work for clients (members). Really great vacation time as well. Pay has drastically increased.
cons: Limited room for growth outside of Chicago offices

job_title: Community Outreach Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Thresholds is a wonderful place to help people experiencing significant and profound disabilities. Paid time off is the best in the field of mental health.
cons: Pay is very low for the amount of stress endured.

job_title: Residential Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: It’s not a stressful place to work.
cons: Working 2nd shift gives you no work life balance.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Wouldn’t trade my experiences there for anything. Learned so much! Mark Ishaug, the CEO is so wonderful.
cons: Low pay and productivity hours

review_title: Supposed Employment department is the best
job_title: Supported Employment Manager in Chicago, IL

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros: Thresholds does important work. They support so many communities in Chicago. Mental health care work is so vital.
cons: The organization is stuck in outdated practices and operations. Leadership can be resistant to change and are adverse to innovation. The salaries for entry level and associate roles are very low resulting in a high turnover. Unfortunately, mental health work is very challenging so it causes a lot of burnout. This burnout mixed with low compensation results in short staffed teams and lack of access to essential care for clients. The constant turnover impacts staff and clients greatly.

job_title: Outreach Worker in Chicago, IL

cons:
Need to work on training
Invest in their employees
The CEO makes a lot of money and we are constantly running out of money in our budget

job_title: Mental Health Practitioner in Chicago, IL

Ability to be part of committees
cons:
Unfortunately, everything else not mentioned below. Lack of safety, mental health support for employees, burnout, underpaid and overworked. Poor work life balance. 

If you love the field, I'd stress do not take a job here... you'll forget why you love psychology in the first place.

review_title: Decent experience but would not recommend
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL

cons:
- Pay is absolutely abysmal. It is unfortunate that as a staff at Thresholds, you put a lot of effort into making a real, substantial difference in one's life, yet you are not rewarded properly. 
- As a CSS, I did not have a great idea of what I was getting myself into, as the job description was elusive and broad. While initially the role was quite impactful and meaniingful, over time I felt like I began to feel like I was just people's b***.

review_title: As diverse as a Klan meeting

pros: Not a thing. Nothing close. Nada!
cons: They brag on how diverse they be, but they full of snot. If you not white or a woman, you better be gay or trans, or they treat you like a slave. They only diverse when it come to members, even then they treat white members better than others. With all the white guilt and black lives matter chitchat, it's a white woman's club, and they wanna keep it that way. Looking for another job so I can get my butt outta here.

review_title: Poor pay but great for consumer
job_title: CSS-1 in Kankakee, IL
pros: Good learning experience. Great for consumer.
cons: Poor pay. Need to increase above poverty wages

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: good benefits and training opportunities
cons: Thresholds is a very hostile work environment. If you are a direct service professional, you have at least six different bosses. The agency is too top heavy, and one department does not want to step on the toes of the other department. Plus, they overwork their employees and give them very little official gratitude. The only time you get a raise is if everyone else in the agency gets a raise. This is why they are able to get good staff but not keep good staff. The average person only stays no more than a year or two. It is devastating to the clients, but the management does not care. Management learned nothing about appreciating their workers even after the pandemic when all of us had to go well above and beyond. We tried to start a union, and while management, including the CEO, would always begin their response to our attempt to start a union with acknowledging our right to unite, they would always brag about the things they give us and how those things would go away if we were to have a union. We even sent a video out to the coworkers about the Union, but today's young professionals have a bad sense of History. They don't care to understand how the unions have helped form workers' rights. When our attempts to organize failed, management went after those who were in the video, firing them for the flimsiest of reasons. I once worked under a director who had written me up simply for not responding to an email right away because I was so busy. The accusation? Insubordination. Insubordination! I tried appealing to human resources employment relations, but that's a waste of time. They don't really listen to the community support specialists, but they always side with management no matter what. Even a manager of employment relations,  who is very nasty and crude. As a Black woman, you would think that she would understand those who had to start at the bottom and who have been mistreated, but she obviously forgot where she came from. In the housing aspect of Thresholds, you have certain clients who have posed a threat to co-workers and the clients have been allowed to stay even after many warnings and many violations. A desk clerk was once beaten up by a drug pusher that a client brought into the building after being told many times not to. Just recently, a male coworker was sexually assaulted by a male client. Instead of going to the police, which was his right, he only reported it to management, confident that they would do something about it. At first, they started planning to evict this client, but they changed their minds. The reason? Because the client apologized! Is that a load of bull or what! I tried talking to employee relations  about it as well as my director, and my director's supervisor, but they still did nothing about it, and employee relations turned my complaint over to the my director's supervisor and told me that she didn't want to hear it because it was not an employee relations matter! I can't even transfer from one site to the other. I would try to apply to a location closer to home, go through the interview and everything, but even though I had been with the agency for years and had gotten good annual reviews, they still won't hire me. At one place on the southside, the director I interviewed with told lies about me to justify not hiring me. As a Black man, you would think he would know a thing or two about discrimination. On top of this, my supervisors broke an agreement whenever I was split between sites whenever there was a staff shortage, and everyone, including the team leader, told me to just deal with it. Well, first, I like to be kissed before I get screwed, and second, don't spit in my face and tell me it's raining. Every year when we are given the survey for Chicago's best and brightest top 101 workplaces, I always give a very candid review of the agency, and every year Thresholds wins. What did the higher-ups have to do to get this every year when they only deserve it because of benefits, morale notwithstanding? With the troubled clients that I enjoyed working with, the third parties, and all others involved, the worst part of the job was dealing with callous and power-hungry management. Yes, this agency and their leadership have broken my heart thoroughly, and they killed my morale. The new leaders would make so many decisions and micromanage me as if I just graduated yesterday, barely taking time to ask for my input as a veteran. They are very reckless with the hearts of their workers and their ability to do their jobs with the clientele. This year, we were offered $1,000 to refer our friends to Thresholds for employment, but I would not refer my enemies to this place. If you see an advertisement for an opening at Thresholds, press delete. If someone comes to you trying to get you to apply, run!

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros:

- every job after this one will feel easy
cons:

- high expectations with minimal support; ignoring concerns about stress level and work load 
- frequent turnover hurts employee moral and damages relationships with clients 
- atrociously low pay even for a non-profit

- killing union efforts and littering the office with anti-union propaganda.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros: The benefits are pretty good!
cons:
Staff is competitive'
Zero treatment for members.

job_title: Employment Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: I receive lots of support from leadership
cons: Busy schedule and high quotas

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros:
Lots of experience in working with members living with SMI in a community setting.
Fellow CSS are amazing and have their heart in the right place to do this work.
You work in a collaborative setting with a team of other clinicians which provides opportunities for sharing ideas and getting input from other perspectives.
cons:
This job was hugely detrimental to my mental health. 
The pay is low in general in this field but especially low at Thresholds. 
The work is difficult by nature at times and I did not receive any meaningful support from higher ups.
Program leaders do not care about employee wellness on lower levels, are not willing to make program changes for well being of staff or members.
Team supervisors attempt to provide support but are also stuck on the same burning ship and have little power to do anything to provide meaningful support beyond keeping their own head above order. 
Condescending communication from program leaders and supervisors, expectation that staff boundaries will be violated in order to do the work and blame placed on staff for program shortcomings. 
There is too much work to humanly accomplish during a work day... expected to work 45-50 hours a week in order to accomplish workload. 
Productivity requirements for billing insurance is prioritized over wellness of staff or actual services delivered to members. 
Staff turnover is high, teams are understaffed, no attention from higher ups in company to remedy this or address long-standing issues. 
Work is super fast paced and requires a lot of crisis management. Many clients are upset (understandably so) and staff who actually do the work in the field receive the brunt of this frustration.

job_title: Case Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Ok place to work... Clients are a little scary

review_title: Terrible pay and lack of supervision for very hard work
job_title: Community Support Specialist II in Chicago, IL
pros: You can gain a lot of experience and knowledge working with individuals with severe and persistent mental illness at Thresholds. For those working toward licensure, you can accrue hours (but more on that in the cons). The new employee orientation was very thorough and benefits were decent. Schedule can be somewhat flexible (if you finish all your visits for the day before 5 pm you can head home and type up case notes remotely).
cons: Okay, about those licensing hours...as a member of a CSS team, I was told that Team Leaders were too busy to provide individual supervision for those working toward their LCSW and that group supervision was not offered to anyone whose Team Leader was an LCSW. I was told to count the morning team meetings as supervision, which under Illinois does technically count but it's not sufficient, particularly for new grads. This is difficult work and if Thresholds wants to support its staff, they need to offer actual supervision. They also need to compensate fairly. Again, this job is grueling. You're driving around all day, often without time to eat, trying to see members and hit your quota (which is next to impossible) and the starting pay is $32K? That's crap. I took the job because I was desperate but left very quickly. It's just not worth it. Also, the CSS teams need to work on a more streamlined new staff training and operating with better communication as things were constantly falling through the cracks.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Awesome staff and supportive team leaders.
cons: Terrible pay and high pressure for billing

review_title: Best treatment agency in the city for people who have mental illness
job_title: Level III in Chicago, IL
pros: Supervisors are extremely supportive.  In the current fee for service environment, Thresholds has done some creative things to reward people for performance.  Recently there was an IPAD mini drawing for the people  who put the most clients on the CHA wait list.  It's a win-win!  Thresholds has the best staff training program in the city, and probably one of the best in the nation.  Evidence based practices are taught and emphasized.  Plenty of opportunity to develop clinical skills like motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral techniques.  Teams are tight and supportive.  People have fun at work.  Witness the ever changing holiday decorations made of colored condom packages in one of the team rooms.  Pay is low, but hey, did you think you were working at a law firm or in corporate sales?  I don't think pay is the motivator for the people who work there.  They truly want to help people.
cons: All I can say is that social workers should make more money.  They don't here, or anywhere else that does this kind of work.

job_title: Community Support Specialist III in Chicago, IL
pros: Exposure to many individuals with various diagnoses. You'll actually work with clients who have diagnoses you read about in the DSM.
cons: NO work life balance. LOW pay, it's hard to live off the pay. Lots of wear and tear on your car. Spending your own money on clients. Expectation that you HAVE the money to spend on clients (i.e. Paying for meals, parking etc). Exposure to unkept homes at times and possible bedbugs from clients. No true advocacy or push for independence as you take clients EVERYWHERE (doctors appts, social security, psychiatry appts, grocery store, shopping for clothes etc). It's great that you're helping them access certain things but then the expectation that you take them everywhere is set. Unreasonable expectations for notes/ billing.

review_title: Awful pay. Stressful work conditions, but the services you will provide are greatly needed.
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros:
-Gained invaluable professional experience (in large part due to my great team leader) *Please note that team leaders can make or break your entire experience. I was just lucky enough to be on a great team. 
-Pretty good benefits. Ample vacation and sick days. (However, I was not able to use many days due to obligations to my team and my members)
-Most of the members are awesome people
-Mileage reimbursement
cons:
-Extremely low salaries for what is required of you (Many of the people I worked with are living paycheck to paycheck)
-Wear and tear on your car. Do not take this position unless you like driving. 
-High stress (Bad work/life balance) Also, we rarely had time to eat lunch or use the bathroom when we were going from member to member. No one cares, but maybe this will change in the future. 
-Unrealistic expectations ( Notes and daily quotas for time spent with members)

review_title: Low Pay, Raises Are Minimal and Not Performance Based.
job_title: Case Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Great vision and commitment to people with mental illness and homelessness. Excellent affordable benefits package.
cons: Poor supervision. Poor guidance. Workers don't feel appreciated and are overworked. Pay is not commesurate with heavy caseloads and tons of documentation and working after hours. If you are a hard worker you will  get a cost of living raise. If you are a lazy do nothing worker, you will also get the same cost of living raise and you get to stay employed ,regardless. Advancement means little but it works if  you know someone in the upper echelon and they helped you get there. (Thats' where the real pay is). Promotions are not always performance-based.

review_title: This job will break your heart--especially with directors and VPs
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Genuine, educative, appreciative clients, hardworking, dedicated to their jobs
cons: Always driving, never getting pay deserved, you are ignored when you do well but ripped apart for the slightest mistake, racial discrimination, each DSP has 6-8 bosses, money is more important than respect and dignity of the clients and DSPs, constant turnover, but nobody gives a hoot.

review_title: A Great Mission but Terrible Management
job_title: Community Support Specialist III in Chicago, IL
pros: The mission to help our members reclaim their lives and independence.
cons: Upper Management and the executive team are very disconnected from the day-to-day reality of the direct service personnel. The impression I have witnessed with regards to management is that they care more about the image of themselves, and their self-serving agendas. Pay raises almost never happen and are geared toward those upper management individuals not the revenue generating staff. Working for Thresholds starts off leaving you feeling inspired but ends with you feeling used. If you like being overworked, underpaid, and constantly stressed out about unreasonable expectations, then this is the company for you!

job_title: Employment Specialist in North Chicago, IL
pros: The biggest benefit of working for this agency is the population it serves. It is very rewarding for those both entry level and those that have many years of experience. I wouldn't trade the experience for anything.
cons: The work load is ridiculous, you're always taking work home, you're never off the clock because clients have your personal cell numbers.  It's not about helping the clients, it's about how many notes you can put into the system to make money. There is a pretend family atmosphere which is why the clients don't trust any of the staff.

job_title: Team Leader in Chicago, IL
pros: Some of the micro cultures, depending on the team you work on, can be outstanding. The trainings, and continued trainings are wonderful. I truly enjoyed the work and felt proud of who I worked for. I started as a community outreach worker and became a Team Leader. Being exposed to other agencies, Thresholds really does an outstanding job. Management is very understanding and present. They do the work as well and are connected to the clients as well as staff. They have been able to withstand serious budget problems.
cons: Pay and parking your car

review_title: Mistreated, take members word over staffs'
job_title: CSS/CRSS in Chicago, IL
pros: Members are great, constantly learning from them and being challenged as a social worker, work individually which can be a nice break from working with the team, work itself is fairly flexible depending on who your team leader is
cons: constantly looking for parking is annoying, case notes are tedious and difficult to keep up with if you're giving members adequate time during visits, work/life balance is difficult to maintain, leadership takes members' words over staffs' in given discrepancies, I was mistreated and turned into a scapegoat for situations I had no control over, I continued to be mistreated after being terminated– lies, deceit, injustice, dishonesty

job_title: Employment Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Working at Thresholds really changed my outlook on life and gave me experiences I will take with me for the rest of my career. The training for ES was very valuable and if you're interested in vocational rehabilitation, Thresholds has the best of the best supported employment department, hands down. The team I worked for was extremely skilled and came from different backgrounds which really contributed to the services provided and my day. The benefits were similar to many other agencies. There is plenty of room for growth. I am really going to miss the staff and my members.
cons: The software and technology could use some reworking. It freezes often and doesn't always save.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: The people who work at Thresholds are among the most compassionate, encouraging and kind people I have ever known.  Period.  There's no gossip, no back-biting, not office politics.  I've been working there for almost three years and have experienced nothing but encouragement and positive energy in every job I've had there.
cons: As it is a non profit, no one is going to get rich working there!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros:
Great mission 
Great people 
The company has great intentions and I think most people would support the ideals that the company is based on. Great people doing the orientation.
cons: The company seemed to have taken on too many new projects when I was employed there. Overall the staff seemed overwhelmed and uninformed as to all of the changes being made.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: The opportunity to work with many different people from all over the cook county area and beyond. Clinical experience and innovative pilot programs can really build your experience quick. Getting clinical supervision hours. Flexible, friendly, open culture, and rewarding work. Being a community support specialist, you really get to know the city, especially in the areas that are often covered by mainstream news.
cons: Not enough staff diversity, especially with staff who are bilingual that can reflect the diversity of the City of Chicago. We definitely lose a lot of members because of language/cultural understanding barriers. Pay is horrible, especially in comparison to other agencies. Compensation for usage of personal vechile is horrible. The amount of driving puts a lot of stress on your vehicle. Maintance and repairs will exceed the compensation, especially if you have an older/used vechile. There is a bit of uncertainty when it comes to vehicle maintainence,  as maintaining my vechile takes take and stress, management usually asks us to use flex time if maintainence eats into scheduled business hours. After while, being able to separate work life and personal becomes blurred due to burn out. Management is concerned of burn out, but there is no real solution, as main reason for burn out is producitivity hours, expectations, and low wages. Concerns that are addressed to team leaders do not get further than PDs, and when they get to VPs, initial concerns were first brought up months prior or management are busy working on other concerns. There tends to be no solution or soluations are long awaited, which exacerbates the issue, causing for more concerns. Then sooner than you realize, the program closes or we lose good staff. And majority of the time, the issue doesn't get resolved due to "the budget", even though staff assists with brainstorming solutions and provides ideas to improve programs. Your voice isn't heard.

review_title: Horrible Upper Management (VP's, Managers, Directors, CEO)
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros: The staff who care about our memeber do indeed really care, and it shows. The msision as a whole and the services provided are life chanigng (and life saving) for the members.
cons:
Lack of accountability form the top down
Groutesquly low salaies
Self Serving Agendas from the top down
Very poor management
Managment who is pasisve aggresive
Management cares more about Image vs actual reality

job_title: Team Leader in Chicago, IL
pros:
They give you a lot of opportunity to make an impact. 
You never have to worry about CEUs or clinical supervision
You get a lot of vacation and sick time.
Coworkers are usually great and down to earth.
cons:
Upper management is very hypocritical in their approach, as much as they say they care about clinical staff they tend to take advantage of floor staff's willingness to go above and beyond to get away with refusing to increase pay for college-educated staff that will go years without a raise.
Upper management prioritizes its members over its own clinical staff. I have often observed that members have more access to supervisors than the clinical team which has led to situations where members have believably threatened to get staff fired.
Upper management does not protect its clinical teams and often creates physically dangerous situations for its clinical staff by refusing to address violent members or demanding staff operate in potentially dangerous environments with limited backup.
I watched upper management inappropriately squash a unionization attempt by telling everyone how wonderful Thresholds used to be with its clinical staff but refusing to make any compromises for upset staff.
Upper management has expressly stated his staffing goal is just to hire people out of college and only expect them to stay 2 years as they expect not to pay them any more for their time and so they operate long term clinical services with a revolving door staff roster.
Floor staff are often expected to complete 5+ hours of clinical billing per day and often don't have enough computers or office space for their staff to complete the billing.
Much of their HR department is straight from Stroger Hospital which is widely known for abusive work environments. Their quality of work has not improved since transitioning from Cook County.
I've watched managers tell staff to do whatever the members want which often led staff to feel like glorified taxi drivers for members and then told not to complain or express that feeling.

review_title: If you enjoy working with developmentally and intellectually challenged individuals. This is the place
job_title: Peer Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Great benefit package, promotes self care, on going training and support.
cons: management pick and choose their favorites, there are employees who literally can be present at work & DO NOTHING! L.R.  isn't fair toward all employee. If you are gonna show favoritism to certain employees that you are very fond of.......Then do not rub it into WORKING STAFF faces.

review_title: Great staff members, but the job is stressful
job_title: Therapist LCPC in Chicago, IL
pros: -The staff and supervisors are very supportive, understanding and treat their employees well. I never had a problem with being treated poorly or being told that I'm too sensitive. I could express how I felt with staff.  If you're burnt out, they will listen to you and try to help.  The environment is also laid-back. I made some good friends here.
cons: You are over-worked and underpaid. The staff is aware of this.  It's more case management than counseling. Clients can be chronically mentally ill and draining.

job_title: CSS in Chicago, IL
pros: Great experience for young counselors starting to get their feet wet in his field. Opportunity for educational growth, promotions based on performance not seniority, meaning the right people are chose for the job. Tons of support from the team leads and program directors. Quality trainings offered all the time to improve clinical skills and for CEUs. Benefits and time off are generous. Open door policy with direct supervisors, and they actually mean it. Love my team and our culture. The communication is positive and strong and I feel safe and heard by them.
cons: I'm more bummed about the direct staff that are threatening our culture and services to members by trying to unionize. They complain that they aren't heard by upper management but have never tried to talk to them? I reached out directly to my programs VP and was responded to honestly and quickly. Thresholds offered to open their books to provide the transparency that the pro union complained about regarding where their money goes and when they did, those that want to unionize didn't even bother to show. I'm conflicted because these are my peers but I'm confused on what they want if they aren't willing to talk to upper management or receive the transparency they so greatly demand. Feels like a bunch of entitled people who want more money but forget this is a systemic problem in our field. No one lied to us that we'd get rich doing this job. If you don't like your pay, leave, or take it up with the governor and Medicare/Medicaid. I'm embarrassed to work with the people who are trying to unionize.

review_title: Challenging, hard work in a supportive community of people devoted to serving people with mental illness.
job_title: Director, Workforce Development in Chicago, IL
pros: Thresholds is an authentic community of people devoted to serving members. There is a lot of room to grow with access to many development opportinities.
cons: The funding goes to members so pay is low. The culture is one of hard work. Don't work here if you aren't willing to work hard, if you are inflexible or easily ruffled.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Providing needed help to members is basically the only positive part. The people that are hired are generally hard working and compassionate.
cons: Poor compensation and lack of support from management. Productivity target is not reasonable. The people who are hired who are compassionate and hard working get burnt out quickly due to the workload and lack of sincere support.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Fellow staff are very dedicated, work/life balance and office culture is great
cons: Management is only concerned about money and expansion, is completely disconnected from the current workforce. Turnover is ridiculous because employees have no reason to stay more than a year or two, since there aren't even cost of living raises, let alone any other compensation for loyalty to the company...

review_title: Extremely tough and personally rewarding but not valued at all by company.
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: You have the opportunity to make valuable, measurable, and lasting impressions on people that are in desperate need of help.
cons: Pay is horrible.  Expectations are not realistic.  Company is top heavy with management who are paid a decent wage.  Most all line jobs require a car with 100/300/100 full coverage insurance and there is no compensation for that.  Never any compensation for overtime.

review_title: Great place to gain experience and move on.
job_title: Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros:
- great place to gain experience, as a stepping stone.
- being able to work with other community partners.
- hands-on experience facing clients.
- good life and work balance.
- flexibility.
cons:
- lack of accountability and transparency 
- no upward mobility (even if you do... most job titles' salaries are not significantly different so it's better to move up to another company/organization.)

job_title: Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Many staff who seem truly committed to the mission.
cons: When you're on a team of people serving people in the community (by going to their homes), your day is structured in such a way that it's difficult to get all the work (particularly notes) done.  They failed to put in place some basic methods that would have made the work 1) take less time, and 2) more effective for the clients. There was a lot of exposure to cigarette smoke (in clients' homes).

job_title: Case Worker in Chicago, IL
pros: The job is very flexible. My team members are awesome and without them I would be very bored. I like getting addition pay for mileage
cons: Management does not advocate their staff. Management is too client driven that they see what is right or wrong because they are afraid the clients will call corporate on them

review_title: Very difficult place to work in an already challenging field.
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Working directly with individuals in need of physical and mental assistance
cons: Their "peer-to-peer" model in which consumers of mental health are deliberately hired (often times in positions of management) seems useful in concept, however, in practice much of the staff have severe mental disorders and as such are difficult to work with.  In many ways working at Thresholds is like emerging yourself in the environment in which you are attempting to aid "member's" (clients) in escaping from.

review_title: Coworkers are great. Management not so much
job_title: Team Leader in Chicago, IL
pros: Flexibility. Good time off and affordable benefits. Great co workers.
cons: Very top heavy.  Upper management is very disconnected and does not respect front line staff. Low pay with high demands.

job_title: Community Support Specialist III in Woodstock, IL
pros: Fantastic, motivated and driven co-workers, highly clinical focus, seeing members make progress toward their recovery goals, affordable benefits and paid time off
cons: Exposure to unkempt homes, cigarette smoke in member's homes, stressful days, and difficulty to maintain a healthy work/ life balance due to billing expectations and documentation

job_title: Supported Employment Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: The best thing about the job is being able to build relationships and advocate for members.
cons: Where do I began?  Leadership will make you believe this is the best place to work.  Just give it time, soon you will realize this is the worst place to work.  Do not believe the "Thresholds Best & Brightest Company to Work For" report.  The report was obviously fictitious and altered. I have never experienced such inefficient leadership.  The leadership at this organization is very unprofessional. They gossip about employees and form cliques.  Morale is extremely low among employees.  The pay is horribly low, not enough to raise/feed a family.  However, employees are required to have a bachelors or masters degree to become employed. Factories and warehouse workers get paid more money without a degree.  Thresholds has a recurrence of bedbug infestation in their residential homes and facilities. However, employees are forced to transport these individuals in their personal vehicles.  Thresholds has had to send pest control to employee homes for treatments.  Let's not discuss the high miles, wear and tear on your vehicle. The best part about the job is being able to advocate and build relationships with some of the members.  However, many of the members you service live in high crime neighborhoods. You are required to bill medicaid for services that may not have been rendered or get written up for productivity.  Employees are told to be creative (unethical !!!) to reach productivity goals set by the agency. My job entailed finding jobs for members who have mental illnesses and drug addictions. Unfortunately, you are held accountable for members not becoming employed when they realistically have multiple barriers.  How do you find a job for individuals who are non adherence to medical treatment, have drug addictions, mental illnesses and do not want to engage???  However, when you job develop (seeking out employers), you lie and tell them you have the best person for the job just to reach your goals. Once a member is hired, you have to practice job retention (helping the member keep the job).  The job, you knew the member would not keep due to their many barriers. The goals are very unrealistic.  Thresholds do not care about their employees or members.  They care about one thing, REVENUE!!!  They are the biggest not-for-profit, for profit agency in the industry.

job_title: Community Support Specialist II in Chicago, IL
pros:
PTO is pretty generous. 
The CEO seem genuinely invested in the company's mission statement.
cons:
This is a very dangerous job if you work on the Southside. We go into dangerous areas everyday and upper management has little regard for this fact. Thresholds puts the lives of the member's before that of its employees. Upper management seems to be extremely out of touch with the reality of this job.

Thresholds has no resources-at least not for it's Southside member's. No housing resources and there are barely any psychiatric or medical providers and the ones they do have are booked months out and provide subpar care. 

They say that offer completive pay but that is not true. The pay here is ridiculously low. Many people have a second job to supplement their income. 

They are not training leaders here, they are producing "yes men". Voicing concerns or disagreeing with the effectiveness of something will lead to you be labeled as difficult and you will be encouraged to "buy in" to whatever upper management is selling.

Thresholds has very few specialist and therapist-so it mandates that it's line staff attend countless trainings to become "specialist" overnight on serious topics such a trauma, ptsd, substance use, etc.

Productivity goals are impossible. The notes you have to do our time consuming and can become overwhelming if you don't stay on top of them. You may find yourself doing notes over the weekend because you are required to have them in by a certain time and the weekends count towards your lag.

job_title: Team Leader in Chicago, IL
pros: Very person-centered approach to mental health recovery, excellent mission, and a lot of opportunity for growth within the agency.
cons: Pay is not comparable to the demands of the job, often asked to do more than is feasible within a typical work day.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Helping clients who truly need support, encouragement, resources, and help improving their lives
cons: Management that expects workers to get documentation done (unpaid) on their own time. Benefits don't start until 3 months after hire.

review_title: Great job for beginning counselors and MHP
job_title: QUALIFIED MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONAL in Chicago, IL
pros: Flexible schedule, building relationship with clients, supervision hours towards licensure offered, opportunities for growth in agency
cons: Having to meet productivity requirements, a lot of pressure to meet billing requirements, extremely low pay and very high demands, a lot of paperwork and case management work,

review_title: Decent for an entry level job out of graduate school, but not the environment for me.  Overall, I would never return.
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: The organization offers an okay salary and good benefits.  It also gives you experience working with those who are marginalized.
cons: There are many.  The worst are the inexperienced staff and their passive aggressive attitude.  There is also little supervision and support.

review_title: Depends on the specific program you work for!
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Overall, the organization does a lot of good for a lot of under served people. The work can be very fufilling.
cons: There are drastic differences in quality of work environment and supervisors between programs. The pay isn't great and there is a lot of tedious paperwork (Medicaid), but this is status quo for social services organizations.

job_title: Development in Chicago, IL
pros: I loved my team and felt rewarded by the work we did. It felt good to be helping people.
cons: Bureaucracy can be frustrating sometimes and due to budgetary restrictions we weren't able to get any performance-based raises, so it deincentivized some employees from giving the job their all.

job_title: Desk Clerk in Chicago, IL
pros: Thresholds is a great place to work because there are different opportunities for advancement in the mental health field. The other staff are good to work with. The training is very informative.
cons: The one disadvntage that I can see to working at thresholds is the pay rate however because of the work the staff does with the members it is rewarding in that way.

review_title: Nice place to work. Opportunities to move up
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: There is Mileage reimbursement for those that work in the community. Bonuses for productivity (if there's a budget). Lots of training and supervision opportunities for social workers and LCPCs.
cons: Pay isn't that great. Due to not having a budget (I'm assuming) there is little to no bonuses for teams when they receive 100% productivity as promised.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros: Great Company, really focuses on the needs of others and does a good job providing relevant resources. Flexible, provided a laptop and internet service to work from home.
cons: Unexpected lay offs, eliminations of positions without notice. My biggest issue was the lack of communication with upper management and the rise of the billing requirements.

job_title: Residential Support Specialist in North Chicago, IL
pros: They care about their employees. They give you a lot of training. The benefits are very good. health insurance, retirement, vacation time.
cons: There really are not many cons. The people are great to work with. The staff are great and the clients are wonderful.

job_title: Service Center Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: Everyone is friendly and helpful. The work is interesting but there’s also downtime so it’s not super busy all the time. Every supervisor in the department has pitched in at least once when we needed help answering calls.
cons: Pay could be better but also not the worst for this specific job

job_title: Janitor in Chicago, IL
pros: It cares about its employees, it treats us very well and it is a friendly atmosphere to work in.
cons: There are no cons to working for this company except that it is in Chicago and the weather can be extremely cold.

review_title: Thresholds attempts to do good work
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent benefits, including vacation and holidays, flexible. Day to day scheduling changes so it's a stimulating environment and definitely not boring.
cons:
Unsafe work conditions
Upper management not supportive
Have to ignore personal beliefs to maintain bottom line
High turnover
Low wages
Focus on billing instead of working with clients

job_title: Service Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Potential for valuable experience if looking to go into mental health occupations.
cons: Low salary compensation, barely living wages for professional  masters level workers.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Great experience working with many different systems within the community. Love working with the members- that's the best part of my job!
cons: Low wages, Stressful work requirements, management disconnected from their outreach workers.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Great Team Work and Supervision opportunities; My team leaders were always available to offer support or direction when needed.
cons: Spend quite a bit of personal time completing tasks including written notes and offering support to clients with severe mental health needs.

job_title: Care Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: The people you work with are the greatest coworke fe s I have ever had.
cons: None identified.  Seriously a great place to work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros: Very Good benefits and very dedicated people. Good management and opportunities to move around. Also very good professional development opportunities
cons: As with most social service agencies, not the best pay when compared to other industries, but good for the industry!

job_title: Community Support Specialist II in Chicago, IL
pros: Teamwork supported, Always working to improve.
cons: The wages are not as much as they could be for the work done. The mindset seems to be leaning more toward the bottom line than care.

job_title: Evaluation Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Vacation hours, community, mission, flexibility
cons: The salary is very low and there are almost never options for a raise.

job_title: Office Manager/Clerk in Chicago, IL
pros: Not a lot of money, but if you work in the Social service's area, expect that at any company.
cons: The work will make you feel productive. One has to love this type of work.

job_title: Case Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: That I was employed. Some of  the staff were nice. I liked being outside of the office, but not all day long.
cons: Pay is below average. Expectations are ridiculous and interfere with quality service delivery.. Supervisors don't effectively supervise. Management is top heavy and makes the big bucks.

job_title: Community Support Masters in McHenry, IL
pros: Passionate workers, solid mission and vision. Ongoing trainings for continued education . Decent vacation time offered.
cons: Low pay for the workload. Some positions can be isolating working independently.

job_title: Community/Peer Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Company has a good heart and intention
cons: Pay very low wages and have unrealistic goal which creates a work/life that is out of balance.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros: great mission, potential for to impact the community, work with a lot of passionate and talented people
cons: financial management and procedures are messy, upper management doesn't care about lower-level employees, low pay

job_title: Finance in Chicago, IL
pros: Strong, supportive mission; good, caring front line staff; established culture; respected leader in healthcare industry.
cons: Employees are extremely dedicated. Sometimes the work effort is taken for granted..

job_title: Social Worker/Case Management in Chicago, IL
pros: Great Benefits and PTO days are excellent
cons: Compensation is poor due to the state budget and it being a non profit organization I guess

job_title: Supported Employment Specialist in Woodstock, IL
pros: Good work/life balance. Very supportive management. Great benefits. Good place to get experience.
cons: People with Bachelor's and Master's degrees make under 40,000 a year.

job_title: Community Support Specialist II in Chicago, IL
pros:
Pretty Flexible Hours
Helping people work towards recovery

Can be emotionally draining
terrible pay
depending on your site poor management
Daily notes can be time consuming

review_title: Great company to work for overall
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Great opportunities for growth and training. Positive work environment and supportive management.
cons: High productivity expectations leading to burnout. Low pay.

job_title: Team Leader in Chicago, IL
pros: Experience and opportunities to advance
cons: Hard work but rewarding. Often work more than 40 hrs

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chicago, IL
pros: Working with the members is gratifying.

review_title: Supportive environment to work in the Justice Dept.

review_title: Prepare to put mileage on your car

review_title: Rewarding psycho-soical work with great team
job_title: Community Support Specialist III in Chicago, IL

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Chicago, IL

review_title: I Heard It Was Better Before My Time Spent There
job_title: Social Worker/Case Manager in Chicago, IL

job_title: Supported Employment Specialist in Chicago, IL

review_title: Terrible working condtions and no respect for the working man or woman
job_title: in Chicago, IL
